Award.AwardTitle: Structures and Mechanisms of Two Enzymes that Produce Hydrocarbon Fuels from Abundant Metabolites
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award the "Chemistry of Life Processes" program of the "Division of Chemistry" is supporting work at the Pennsylvania State University to study two enzymes that catalyze key steps in the conversion of fatty acids (abundant and common cellular metabolites) to hydrocarbons (alkanes and alkenes). These can then be used as drop-in biofuels for combustion engines. The research supported is impacting development of renewable energy, because the use of microorganisms is a promising strategy for biofuel production. This process is particularly environmentally friendly, because it is ultimately carbon neutral and driven by solar energy. The project is studying how the enzymes described above function with an eye to importing them into genetically engineered microorganisms which can produce biofuels. Work supported by this award is also offering students and postdoctoral scholars opportunities to be broadly trained in biophysical methods. It also supports a biennial workshop, led by Penn State metallobiochemists and supported by colleagues from other institutions, that trains students and postdoctoral scholars in unique methods used in this research field.

Genetically manipulable microorganisms that could (i) produce fatty acids from sunlight and carbon dioxide (either directly by using photosynthetic cyanobacteria, or indirectly by feeding the engineered microorganisms sugars obtained from fast-growing and high-yielding plants such as sugar cane) and (ii) convert the fatty acids into "drop-in" biofuels are actively pursued as vehicles for biogenesis of renewable fuels. Two recently discovered enzyme pathways for the conversion of fatty acids into linear alkane or alkene hydrocarbons involve enzymes that harbor iron-containing cofactors at their active site. The first example involves the two-step alkane biosynthesis pathway in cyanobacteria that converts fatty acids via fatty aldehydes to alk(a/e)nes. The second step in this pathway is catalyzed by the enzyme aldehyde-deformylating oxygenase (ADO), a member of the ferritin-like diiron-carboxylate oxidases and oxygenases. In the previous funding cycle we studied the ADO reaction as a novel, cryptically redox oxygenation reaction. Further mechanistic studies revealed potential inefficiencies and vulnerabilities that could limit the usefulness of this pathway for biofuel production. We propose to study the reaction of ADO in greater depth, with the expectation that further mechanistic insight will guide the rational design of biofuel-producing microorganisms. The second example involves a recently discovered iron-enzyme, UndA, that utilizes O2 to decarboxylate fatty acids to carbon dioxide and terminal alkenes. Our preliminary work suggests that UndA is also a diiron enzyme, contrary to the published assumption that it is a mononuclear iron enzyme. We propose to identify the correct cofactor and determine the molecular mechanism in detail. These studies will be an important contribution to ongoing research efforts that aim at utilizing this metabolic pathway for biofuel production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes that utilize a cofactor composed of two iron (Fe) ions bridged by protein-derived carboxylate groups catalyze a wide range of oxidation reactions. These reactions are chemically very difficult and biologically very important. For example, these enzymes catalyze steps in DNA biosynthesis and repair; the conversion of the greenhouse gas, methane, to the commodity chemical, methanol; the conversion of abundant fatty acids into alkanes, which could serve as drop-in biofuels for combustion engines; or they install specific chemical functional groups in the biosyntheses of various antibiotics. Our aim in studying these enzymes is to understand how they perform these difficult reactions (termed the "mechanism"). The ultimate goal of this research area is to develop tools to rationally redesign these enzymes (based on understanding their mechanisms) and thereby harness their great potential for societally-relevant applications (e.g. the design of new antibiotics or production of biofuels). These enzymes have in common that they utilize the ultimate green oxidant, atmospheric dioxygen, at their reduced Fe(II)/Fe(II) cofactors to generate a first common intermediate, in which two electrons are transferred from the Fe(II) ions to O2, yielding a peroxo (O22-)-Fe(III)/Fe(III) intermediate. Although this intermediate is common to the various members of this family, each enzyme directs the reactivity of the intermediate to a different outcome; it is thought that enzymes do this by subtly tweaking the geometric and electronic structure of the intermediate. Thus, a detailed understanding of the structure of these intermediates and their reactivities is the foundation for rational reprogramming efforts.

 

Genetically manipulable microorganisms that could produce “drop-in” biofuels from sunlight and carbon dioxide are actively pursued as vehicles for biogenesis of renewable fuels. Two recently discovered enzyme pathways for the conversion of fatty acids into linear alkane or alkene hydrocarbons involve enzymes that harbor iron-containing cofactors at their active site. The first example involves the two-step alkane biosynthesis pathway in cyanobacteria that converts fatty acids via fatty aldehydes to alk(a/e)nes. The second step in this pathway is catalyzed by the enzyme aldehyde-deformylating oxygenase (ADO), a member of the ferritin-like diiron-carboxylate oxidases and oxygenases. With support from this award, we continued to study the reaction of ADO in greater depth. We characterized the structure of the key intermediate, a peroxy-hemiacetal-diiron(III/III) complex, in greater depth and we characterized the mechanism of reaction of ADO with hydrogen peroxide, which is known to inactivate the enzyme. The second example involves a recently discovered iron-enzyme, UndA, that utilizes O2 to decarboxylate fatty acids to CO2 and terminal alkenes. Contrary to the published assumption that UndA requires one iron atoms for its activity, our work supported by this award showed that UndA requires a diiron cofactor for its activity. We have studied the mechanism of the reaction UndA and identified a key reaction intermediate, a peroxo-diiron(III/III) complex. Our studies on the ADO and UndA enzymes are an important contribution to ongoing research efforts that aim at utilizing these metabolic pathways for biofuel production.

 

The research area of biological inorganic chemistry encompasses a wide variety of subfields, including molecular biology, biochemistry, biophysics, inorganic chemistry, analytical chemistry, physical chemistry, and theoretical chemistry, as well as many different methods, such as biochemical characterization of enzymes, reaction kinetics, a plethora of spectroscopic techniques, and computational methods. Because of this broad range of areas and techniques, it is important that researchers working in this field have a good, basic, working knowledge of many methods and approaches employed in the field, in order to design and discuss experiments with collaborators. Therefore, the training of students working in bioinorganic chemistry is an important aspect of this field. Since 2010, the bioinorganic chemists at Penn State offer workshops for training of the next generation of bioinorganic chemists; these efforts are led by the co-PIs. After a smaller “trial workshop” in 2010, the Penn State bioinorganic group, the Penn State bioinorganic group hosted workshops biennially since 2012. These workshops typically have ~150 participants and include (i) ~15 lectures given by faculty experts, (ii) hands-on training in small groups in ~20 methods, and (iii) presentation of the participants’ research by oral and poster presentations. The centerpiece of the workshops is the hands-on training, in which approximately half of the participants from all ranks (undergraduate students to faculty) served as teachers. During these practicals, the traditional roles of teachers and students were reversed to the extent that undergraduate students taught faculty in the students' areas of specialty. Thus far, the Penn State bioinorganic workshops had ~500 participants (mostly students and postdocs), of which ~50 have obtained a job in academia and who continue to work together. Thus, the workshops not only play a key role in training, but also in facilitating research in bioinorganic chemistry and help establishing future collaborations among “workshop alumni” to carry out research in bioinorganic chemistry that will address many important topics relevant to society.
